back: A stochastic system with one or more inputs and one or more outputs, for which the output(s) is(are) not a deterministic function of the output(s)

For a stochastic system with a discrete input events $\{ A_0, A_i, \ldots \}$ and discrete output events $\{B_0, B_1, \ldots\}$, the likelihoods are the conditional probabilities of the output events given the input events: \[ P(B_j| A_i). \]

For a stochastic system with discrete input events $\{ A_0, A_i, \ldots \}$ and discrete output events $\{B_0, B_1, \ldots\}$, the a posterior probabilities (APPs) are the conditional probabilities of the input events given the observed outputs: \[ P(A_i | B_j). \]
For a stochastic system with discrete input events $\{ A_0, A_i, \ldots \}$, the a priori probabilities are the probabilities of the input events before any output is observed: \[ P(A_i). \]

Given likelihoods $P(B_j|A_i)$ and a prioris $P(A_i)$, the a posteriori probabilities (APPs) can be written as \[ P(A_i|B_j) = \frac{P\left(B_j \left \vert A_i \right. \right) P\left( A_i \right)} { \sum_i P\left(B_j \left \vert A_i \right. \right) P\left( A_i \right)} \]
Assuming the likelihoods will determine the probabilities and negelecting the a prioris, which give some base rate at which one of the phenomena occurs.
An internal state (for example, memory contents) of a system that can affect outputs but that is not directly observable.

For a discrete stochastic system with inputs (or hidden states) $\{A_i\}$ and outputs $\{B_j\}$, a decision rule for an observation $B_j$ gives a choice of corresponding input event $A_i$.
The decision rule may be chosen to optimize some function of the inputs and outputs (e.g., likelihood or APP).

For a stochastic system with a discrete input events $\{ A_0, A_i, \ldots \}$ and discrete output events $\{B_0, B_1, \ldots\}$, the maximum likelihood decision rule given $B_j$ was received is
$$ \hat{A}_i, \mbox{ where } i = \arg \max_{i \in \{0,1\}} P(B_j|A_i). $$

For a stochastic system with a discrete input events $\{ A_0, A_i, \ldots \}$ and discrete output events $\{B_0, B_1, \ldots\}$, the maximum a posteriori (MAP) decision rule given $B_j$ was received is
$$ \hat{A}_i, \mbox{ where } i = \arg \max_{i \in \{0,1\}} P(A_i|B_j). $$
A collection of a priori probabilities that do not give preference to any of the outcomes; usually flat (constant) across the set of outcomes.
A collection of a priori probabilities that are based on information that are external to the data and that are usually not flat (constant) across the set of outcomes.
A $C$% credible interval is an interval of values that contains $C$% of the a posteriori probability.
